Brands, 'they call them marks (marchae), stamped on bundles audon chests of merchandise do not furnish full proof of the owner· ship of the merchandise3 they furnish a presumptive and unreliable proof, as Straccha well puts it, and on this point Menochius and the others teach the same doctrine. Eut even before Straccha others have taught this, so that undoubtedly tbis is the common view. b“ The letters of merchants in accordante with usage are said to have tbe force of public recorda, and are accepted by everybody.” eThis is true, too, of the documents from the collectors of revenue, dbut these letters, to be used as proof, must be acknowledged. However, it is an accepted principle that letters not acknowledged are certified by a comparison [sc. with other letters where the writer is known], and the same practice would hold for account-books. eIn the case of receipts the principle would not be the same, unless the said receipt, which has not been acknowledged‚ has the signatore of three witnesses; with another receipt it is not possible to secure a comparison. And the reason for the differente is that the party interested in the case of a receipt ought to take the consequences upon himself if the business was not carried out in due form. On these points Straccha holds the same opinion, and concerning the comparison of the letters he also mentions something else to the same effect, which I do not set down. ‘Other writers too remark in the same way on the difficulty of proving a private document, even a docu- ment between merchants.
